abstract.p: The most important problem related to internal wave observation is that it is difficult to obtain clear results with in-situ observations. There are many factors, including the topography, time, season, wind and temperature, which may affect the shape of the wave, perhaps even making it disappear or not leave strong evidence. This paper discusses the research on in-situ observations of such waves in oceans, estuaries and lakes. Over the past decades, researchers have observed this phenomenon and have carried out numerical experiments about these internal solitary waves. They have used high tech equipment and mathematical methods to detect and calculate the results of wave vibration and simulate the in-situ conditions seen during wave turbulence. We focus on the in-situ observation of such waves in oceans, estuaries and lakes, surveying scholarly work over the past few years from a wide variety of places including Europe, the United States, South Africa, Taiwan, the South China Sea and the Yellow Sea. Even now, with the rapid development of new technology for use in in-situ observations, there are still many elements of the behavior of such waves that remain to be solved.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: One of the earliest reports on internal gravity wave (IGW) activities in the ocean dates back to 1893, when Fridtjof Nansen, a Norwegian explorer, observed how the forward motion of his ship was severely retarded while sailing on a thin layer of calm fresh water overlying briny water in an estuary. The phenomenon was then referred to as ‘dead water’ (Bascom, 1980). Later, after having conducted experiments on internal waves, Ekman (1904) confirmed that the motion of the ship generated internal waves that reduced the ship's momentum. However, the theoretical understanding of this phenomenon can be traced back to Stokes (1847) almost 50 years before the first field discovery. In fact, study of oceanic internal waves remained largely limited until the 1970s. Over the past three decades, though, numerous observations of internal wave activities in the ocean have led to a better understanding of their importance in association with many oceanic processes. Among the many scientific studies on internal solitary waves (ISWs), there has been considerable interest in the generation, propagation, interaction and dissipation of internal waves on uniform slopes and over submerged topography. Garrett and Kunze (2007) describe how internal gravity waves propagate disturbances within the body of a stable, density stratified fluid. These waves are important for dissipating barotropic tidal energy in the ocean as well as for transporting linear and angular momentum in the atmosphere (Hines, 1960) and even astrophysical bodies (Charbonnel and Talon, 2005). Understanding of such waves finds applications in deep water drilling (Osbome et al., 1978) and air travel (Clark et al., 2000). They are of interest, for example, in the field of geophysics, where understanding internal wave propagation is very important.

Nonlinear internal waves (NLIW) have been observed in oceanic areas for many years (e.g., Jackson, 2004). They have been found to generate strong shear, which creates conditions favorable for instabilities, producing raised turbulence dissipation and mixing (sources include Inall et al., 2000; Kumar et al., 2010; MacKinnon and Gregg, 2003; Moum et al., 2003). NLIWs may be a basic contributor to the vertical movement of nutrients and heat flux over the continental shelf. Shroyer et al. (2010) observed NLIWs on the New Jersey shelf. They had the use of 25 boats, microstructure profiling and X-band radar to obtain tracking data. Estimates show that these NLIWs are an important factor for two aspects of shelf dynamics, under conditions of weak to moderate atmospheric forcing.

Nonlinear internal waves include solitons and groups of solitons which are usually observable by high-tech equipment capable of measuring in-situ data or radar satellite images of marine or coastal flows. Many studies have been published aimed at this specific field to examine and obtain data near the Stait of Gibraltar, in the Sulu Sea, in the South China Sea and in the Irish Sea (Apel, 2003; Green et al., 2010; Helfrich and Melville, 2006). These types of waves occur when barotropic tidal currents interact with underwater structures such as mountains, ridges, continental shelves and slopes in a stratified oceanic environment. Many studies of topography-related generation mechanisms can be found in the literature. Horizontal propagating internal solitary and ISWs are commonly observed features in the marine field worldwide (Apel et al., 1985; Moum and Smyth, 2006; Osborne and Burch, 1980). The bands are visible in the modulation of surface wave activity by internal waves caused by currents. Internal solitary waves can provide impetus and maintain energy over long distances. Both in the main water column and the bottom boundary layer, there may be substantial mixing due to ISWs (Stastna et al., 2009). Helfrich and Melville (2006) point out that the breaking of ISWs is considered an important contributor of energy in the mixing of coastal fields. In addition, Bourgault et al. (2007) recently discussed how a train of ISWs affect coastlines. One component of that study is a model comparison. It is pointed out that large parts of the general nature and predictability of ISWs cannot be quantified. A solitary wave basically moves at a continuous speed preserving a constant shape. Therefore, these waves are stable enough that the propagating speed of the wave can be plotted in a coordinate system (D’Asaro et al., 2007). On the other hand, there have also been many studies over the last few decades devoted to the influence of areas of fresh water, where the physical, biological and chemical properties of those portions of oceans have been strongly affected by river input (Simpson, 1997). These studies are focused on two different areas; one is the estuary (Jay and Smith, 1990), and the other is far-field river plume (e.g., Fong et al., 1997). In this study, we focus on two aspects of the aforementioned waves, one is the internal waves in the ocean, and the other is in river estuaries.

sec.title: 2. Observation of internal waves in the oceans
sec.p: Internal gravity waves are the motion at an interface of stable density stratification in the interior of the ocean. The stratification of the water column in the ocean may be sharp, with each layer increasing in depth over hundreds of meters (Martin et al., 1998). Changes in salinity in the fluid layer with depth are referred to as haloclines, and changes in temperature of a water layer with depth are called thermoclines. Haloclines occur with fresh river outflows; thermoclines are caused by the interaction of different water masses or currents in the ocean and surface heats from sunshine. Both salinity and temperature are dependent on water depth. Increases in density caused by the increase in depth are called pycnolines. The interface of a stratified fluid often exists at least 50 meters beneath the free surface.

The presence of oceanic internal waves has long being recognized, and is often reflected by the variations in temperature and salinity profiles at fixed depths, particularly near highly stratified thermoclines (Phillips, 1997). As evidenced by reflected sonic signals, acoustic signals can vary considerably in amplitude, travel time and the direction from their source. It was not until the last two decades that the existence of natural variations in the acoustic characteristics of the ocean's interior due to the presence of internal waves has been recognized. Aside from the phenomenon of dead water (causing the retardation of a sailing vessel), internal waves produce visible ‘slicks’, or surface signatures on the free surface of the ocean. The effect of the internal wave is visible as streaks of water or slick marks, which are produced by the convergence of surface particle movement above its troughs (Liu et al., 1998). LeBlond and Mysak (1978) summarized the mechanisms occurring in the interior of oceans where energy exchange takes place due to internal waves. The mechanism includes the processes of energy sources and sinks, whilst others act as energy transfer mechanisms between waves of different lengths, as illustrated in Figure 1. These mechanisms are outlined in detail in the following sections. Figure 1.
Schematic illustration of internal wave mechanisms: (A) interaction with mean flow; (B) dissipation mechanisms; (C) wave to wave interaction; (D) atmospheric disturbance and interaction with surface waves; and (E) flow over the bottom topography.

A nonlinear numerical model has been developed with uninterrupted vertical stratification and tumultuous exchange to describe the internal wave's interaction with variable bottom topography. The model presumes the depression of the horizontal solitary wave with amplitude modulation. The vertical composition is defined by buoyancy frequency profiles. An example is depicted in Figure 2(b). A wave usually propagates from the first deep part with depth H1 (Figure 2(a)) to the second linear continental slope then further to the third shelf. The goal of the modeling is to examine the process of evolution of a solitary internal wave in the second and the third regions during strong overturning and breaking (Vlasenko and Hutter, 2002). Figure 2.
Schematic diagram of the computational area: (a) buoyancy frequency profiles used in the model; (b) waves measured in the Andaman Sea (1, 2); and (3) the Sulu Sea.

Vlasenko and Hutter (2002) simulated the breaking of solitary internal waves over a slope-shelf topography (Figure 2). They found that the breaking event could arise if the wave amplitude am is larger than 0.4 (Hs - Hm), in which Hm is the undisturbed depth of the isopycnal of the maximum depression. Breaking events are also observed during the ASIAEX project in the South China Sea (Duda et al., 2004; Yang et al., 2004); see Figure 3. Yang et al. (2004) apply two methods to examine wave breaking on the China Continental Shelf. The left panel shows the mooring location (21°2.8’ N, 117°13.2’ E, square mark) and surrounding bathymetry. The right panel shows schematic drawings of the moorings in 1999 and 2000. Overall, the breaking criterion suggested from previous studies is that in a two-layer system, the maximum particle velocity is greater than the phase speed (Saffarinia and Kao, 1996) or 0.8 times of the phase speed in continuous stratified fluids (Grue et al., 2000). Helfrich (1992) also suggested that for a0/d-s > 0.4 (where a0 and d-s are the wave amplitude and lower fluid thickness, respectively), strong overturning could occur. Figure 3.
Location map and drawings of the ASIAEX pilot study moorings.

sec.title: 3. Internal wave generation
sec.p: In cases of fluid stratification, additional waves may occur at the interface. These waves evolve at the expense of basic potential energy available in the layering system; instability may arise agitating internal wave generation. Therefore, internal waves in the ocean may be generated by a number of external forces, such as strong wind, tidal motion, ocean current, and fluctuations in atmospheric pressure. Numerous reviews on detailed processes portraying internal wave generation mechanisms have been presented elsewhere. However, considerable uncertainty remains about the way in which energy is supplied to internal waves. Generally speaking, the likely mechanism is similar to the lee wave formation describing the interaction of tidal flow over topographic variations, such as ridges, trenches, seamounts, sills and shelf breaks (Alendal et al., 2005; Azevedo et al., 2006; Baines, 1982; Bell, 1975; Buijsman et al., 2010; Chen, 2007; Chen, 2010; Chen, 2011a; Cushman-Roisin, 1994; Esteves et al., 2001; Farmer and Armi, 1999; Garrett and Munk, 1979; Helfrich et al., 1984; Hibiya, 1986; Hsu et al., 2000; Lamb, 1994, 2004; Liu et al., 1985, 1998; Maxworthy, 1979; Munroe and Lamb, 2005; Thiem and Berntsen, 2009; Thiem et al., 2006; Thorpe, 1975; Yttervik and Furnes, 2005).

Wave generation may also correspond to a baroclinic wave drag and it results in a transfer of energy out of the barotropic tide and into internal (baroclinic) waves. However, Hsieh and Ho (1994) noted that tidal motion over submarine mountain ridges is not always strong enough to upset the generation of internal waves. Phillips (1977) reported that two surface waves with a similar wave number, k and k+äk, can propagate across the ocean surface to form a series of wave groups with a wave number äk. If the group velocity of the surface wave matches the phase velocity of an internal wave with the same wave number of äk, then changes in the resonant energy exchanges can occur. Phillips (1977) considered that, under proper conditions, if the rate of the energy transferred into internal waves is much smaller than that into surface waves, internal waves of significant amplitude can develop. Additional generation mechanisms for internal waves have been reported by Thorpe (1975), who concluded that they should include atmospheric disturbances, such as traveling pressure fields, wind stress, traveling buoyancy flux, interaction with surface waves, etc. In addition to atmospheric generation (Thorpe, 1975), the resonant interaction of a pair of surface waves (Garrett and Munk, 1975), instabilities in the mean current (Muller et al., 1986) and geostrophic adjustment after flow instabilities (Kundu, 1993) are also the likely sources for internal waves. Wind speed and directional data in the middle Adriatic shelf break were analyzed, as a possible internal wave generating force (Leder, 2002). Mechanical energy from traveling winds may also be responsible for the generation of a large fraction of internal waves in the ocean, at all depths, and it is considered that oceanic interior mixing is agitated on the large scale by atmospheric forcing (Kundu, 1993).

sec.title: 4. Experimental in-situ study
sec.p:
The restoring forces resulting from relative buoyancy and gravity are weak. They typically produce internal waves with periods from minutes to hours, wavelengths from tens of meters to several kilometers, and amplitudes from few meters to several tens of meters (Garrett and Munk, 1979; Muller et al., 1986; Olbers, 1983). Oceanographic measurements have recorded internal waves with amplitudes of up to 80 m, the roughness bands associated with one of the internal soliton packets of up to 1200 m (Osborne and Burch, 1980). Amplitudes are often as high as 100 m and wavelengths can be up to about 1600 m. The largest horizontal current velocity, about 2.4 m/s, and wave speed of about 1.8 m/s, were observed in the South China Sea (Yang et al., 2004). Based on internal wave distribution maps from 1993 to 2000 (see Figure 4), Liu and Hsu (2004) reported wave crests as long as 200 km with amplitudes of 100 m, caused by the branching out of a strong current from the Kuroshio into the South China Sea. In comparison, surface waves subjected to the restoring forces of surface tension and gravity have periods of only up to 20 seconds, wave speeds up to tens of meters per second, and amplitudes up to several meters, approximately. Figure 4.
Bathymetry and internal wave distribution in the northeast China Sea.

Xu et al. (2008) developed a nonhydrostatic numerical model and a step-like topography in a simulation of an ISW interaction. They paid particular attention to the breaking process and the change in the wave's energy. The flow pattern could be classified into three categories related to the step topography: 1. the propagation and spatial construction of the ISW was not greatly influenced by the bottom topography; 2. the ISW was remarkably distorted by the blocking effect of the topography without the occurrence of wave breaking; 3. the ISW broke as it encountered and passed over the bottom topography. A particularized description of the processes causing wave breaking and an energy budget analysis are given. The results indicated that the maximum rate of energy dissipation is not over 40%, which is in accordance with the available experimental data.

Garrett and Munk (1979, p339) noted that: ‘an abrupt, or fairly sharp, density interface within the fluid is not essential for the existence of waves that owe their restoring force to gravity; any hydrostatically stable density stratification can support internal waves’.

These waves are able to propagate along the interface for hundreds of kilometers, even after the initial generating mechanism has stopped (Ostrovsky and Stepanyants, 1989). Furthermore, as seen in Figure 5, an elevation-type internal wave can be produced after a depression internal wave passes through a ‘turning point’ of approximately equal layer depth as has been observed in SAR images and simulated by numerical models (Hsu et al., 2000; Liu et al., 1998). However, this is not a static point but rather varies both in space and time (Ramp et al., 2004). Figure 5.
Wave packets consisting of solitons of the depression type with decreasing amplitude.

Researchers have looked at the influence of the proliferation rate in southwestern Taiwan, seeking to understand the effect of the turbulent diffusion of the kinetic parameters in a variety of oceanic environments, based on observing the profile of oceanic areas captured by the Lowered Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (LADCP) and Conductivity, Temperature and Depth Profiler (CTD). Theoretical calculations can be used to obtain the vertical turbulent eddy diffusivity K (vertical eddy diffusivity), the Thorpe scale analysis method is mainly used to calculate Kz, supplemented using the flow shear in the vertical wave number spectrum method to calculate Ksh, for the internal tide, ocean depth, in isolated cases of spread to four different impact of the Kuroshio turbulent diffusion factor (Liang, 2010).

Ibragimov and Ibragimov (2010) showed detailed solutions to the equations of motion for ISWs in a stratified fluid (i.e., by solving the questions and obtaining the model) as invariant solutions, which is about nonlinear equations of motion.) A reproduction of the beam-like structure of internal waves is shown in Figure 6. The invariant solutions are derived using Lie group analysis of differential equations. In particular, the formula shows how one of the invariants that can be deduced from the symmetry of the completely nonlinear formula of motion represents a direction equal to the transverse direction of beam propagation (Ibragimov and Ibragimov, 2010).

caption.p: Reproduction of the beam-like structure of internal waves produced by the back and forth oscillation for a curved two-dimensional topography in a linear stratified environment. The shape of the topography in the experiment is a Gaussian curve.

sec.p: Casagrande et al. (2009) used in-situ data to initialize and evaluate the Lamb model. An Empirical Orthogonal Function (EOF) analysis was applied to the data and the model outputs. The authors found that the first three empirical functions contain over 99% of the variability. The data and the model results are in very good qualitative and quantitative agreement, giving a propagation depth for the ISW train of around 90 m with a pycnocline oscillating from 80 to 130 m. An original method for detecting internal waves was developed using the first two EOFs. This was done by analyzing the scatter diagram for the first EOF projection coefficient versus the second EOF projection coefficient. This distribution has a specific ‘crescent shape’, showing that the first two projection coefficients are not independent in the presence of internal wave events. The crescent shape signature of the internal waves can be used as an internal wave detector. (Casagrande et al., 2010) The Strait of Messina is an important place because of its propensity for internal bore generation and ISW occurrence. The area has a shallow sill and strong tidal currents, which lead to this situation. This study uses empirical orthogonal function analysis to obtain data for the observational area. The most common method for this is statistical analysis, because it is difficult to completely collect the data. The method only uses the first two spatial empirical modes. During internal wave events, the two modes exhibit over 99% of the variability, showing the higher absolute values for their corresponding time-dependent expansion coefficients. In 2009, the first study linking both expansion coefficients was published (Casagrande et al., 2009).

sec.title: 5. Model configuration and experimental study
sec.p: Internal soliton packets and internal tidal frequency bores can carry a significant amount of energy from deeper water into the littoral zone (Howell and Brown, 1985). A number of dissipative mechanisms (e.g., viscosity, friction, etc.) may contribute to the dissipation and absorption of wave energy, yielding progressive attenuation of wave amplitude during the course of propagation. It should be borne in in mind that the scenario of a permanent waveform could not be realized in the laboratory even though it was once referred to by Koop and Butler (1981) and Michallet and Barthelemy (1997, 1998). The concept of universal internal wave spectra implicitly assumes a balance between energy input from a source and energy dissipation into a sink; however, it does not specify the source and sink mechanisms. Dissipation mechanisms for internal waves are still poorly understood in quantitative terms. Wave breaking, shear instability, and attenuation due to viscous effects and turbulent layers are universally dominant processes causing significant energy sinks for internal waves (Thorpe, 1975). Munk (1981) has identified the phenomenon of advective instability, a process that occurs in the interior of the ocean. Additional dissipative mechanisms might include friction with the sea floor, interaction among internal waves, absorption in critical layers, and refraction, diffraction, reflection and transformation while encountering a varying submarine topography. For example, Muller et al. (1986) argued that internal wave energy may also be dissipated by critical reflection at sloping boundaries and adsorption in the bottom boundary layer. This is to be expected, because stronger flow is often exhibited in the boundary regions and steep sloping sites than the interior of oceans and lakes (Eriksen, 1993). Imboden and Wuest (1995) had observed that the shoaling of internal waves over the varying bottom topography would lead to strong bottom shear, which may be responsible for high rates of dissipation.

In those controversial mechanisms, both Phillip (1977) and Garrett and Munk (1979) considered shear instability as being the most prominent in the ocean. After ISWs reach the so-called ‘critical amplitude’, they decay due to shear instabilities. Shear instability may be determined by applying the local Richardson Number (Ri). In continental shelf zones, the increase in bottom turbulence as affected by internal tides will impact sediment transportation and the more widespread exchange between the shelf and the deep bottom ocean. It will also impact vertical nutrient transportation, which has repercussions for phytoplankton growth, depending on the lighting. Briefly, ocean sciences are going through a period of progress and change from the climate change scale to coastal ocean dynamics scale, in which the combination of the interaction of the tides with ocean stratification and circumrotation cannot be ignored. Until now, the hydrodynamic models have almost all drawn conclusions utilizing only a limited range of frequency and horizontal scales for the ocean dynamics. There are challenging tasks that still remain for comprehensive modeling of the internal tide dynamics and the overall range of oceanic dynamics (Pairaud et al., 2008)

In the literature in recent years we find that Warn-Varnas et al. (2009) used scaling parameters in a two-layer analogue configuration to predict numerical solutions with the full nonlinear nonhydrostatic Lamb model. Their modeling is focused on ISWs and acoustics in the Yellow Sea south of the Shandong peninsula. The two aspects of density considered are: 1. variations in density difference across the pycnocline, tidal forcing and topographic height; 2. analyzing parameters indicating the characteristics of solitary waves that depart from a tuned data case. These include changes in the solitary wave's functional form, amplitude, wave length and phase speed (this information is tracked during the experiments). The observational periods from 2002 to 2006 show the existence of large amplitude internal waves with semi-diurnal and super tidal frequency. The study area is in the western Irish Sea (Figure 7). The observational results show the dissipation of turbulent active energy, and theoretical arguments prove that before the dissipation of internal tides, they are not able to propagate over the whole stratified area. The measurements show that the action of these internal tides does cover a wide portion of the area (Green et al., 2010). Figure 7.
Composite IR picture of sea-surface temperature taken in July 2006 (in 2002 the satellite could not obtain a clear picture). The picture shows that a patch of isolated seasonal stratification in the western Irish Sea.

There is a new idea being looked at in this research field. Asymmetric barotropic tides with strong eastward currents contribute westward moving solitons in the internal tide release mechanism. The strong eastward current raises the isotherms higher, allowing the development of a huge potential and strong energy density on the high western side of the ridge. The wave propagates away from the ridge, with solitons being scattered on the back slope. There is a nonlinear increase in the density and strength of the energy of the solitons including asymmetric velocity and energy flux due to lee waves (Figure 8) (Buijsman et al., 2010). Figure 8.

In their study, Pingree and New (1989) found the internal tide to be mainly semi-diurnal, due to the dominance of semi-diurnal M2 barotropic forcing above the shelf break in the Bay of Biscay. This type of generation has also been identified in the northern shelf breaks near the La Chapelle bank (New and Pingree, 1990; Pichon and Correard, 2006) and the Cape Finisterre region off Northwest Spain (Azevedo et al., 2006; Pichon and Correard, 2006). Pinkle and Rudnick (2006) discuss the results of many researchers from various organizations. They shared observations and modeling strategies to quantify the tidal energy transfers that occur over the Hawaiian ridge. Egbert and Ray (2001) have found the barotropic tidal energy dissipated at specific sites along the Hawaiian Island Chain to be 20 GW, which makes up about 2% of the 1 TW global pelagic tidal dissipation. Strong barotropic tidal forcing, the steep slope of the sea-floor (such as at ridges and shelf breaks) and strong stratification gradients (thermoclines) are the three major factors forcing the generation of the internal tide (Vlasenko et al., 2005).

The most common method for studying internal tides is to use harmonic analysis for extraction of the various components of the tidal spectrum. Unfortunately, this does not provide any information about the tidal cycle. Some researchers use a combination of principal component analysis (PCA) and wavelet decomposition to offset this weakness. This method utilizes the wavelet empirical orthogonal functions and is called WEof Analysis. Pairaud and Auclair (2005) described this method in detail in combination with time-frequency wavelet analysis as shown in Farge (1992). It also has another function, that is, spatial PCA for the recognition of coherent physical structures. Pairaud et al. (2010) focus on two parts, one is the baroclinic component of the tides, and the other is the comparison of simulation results with observations from the MINT94 experiment. WEof Analysis can be used to observe the two parts. Figure 9 shows the parameters for observations by WEof analysis. Figure 9.

sec.title: 6. Internal waves in estuaries and lakes
sec.p: Many studies have been dedicated to observing and understanding tidal circulation in estuarine conditions. Results have shown that internal waves may be an important part of the mixing process that occurs in estuaries (Kjerfve, 1988a). The generation and mixing areas, however, are separate in terms of both time and space. It is also discovered that shear instability is the principal mechanism of vertical exchange within the pycnocline of a salt wedge estuary (Geyer and Smith, 1987).

At the estuaries of many rivers, topographic features are thought to play a significant role in the generation of internal waves that propagate upstream. New et al. (1986a) discuss this possibility, and the subsequent intense mixing periods. They suggest that as the flood tide flows over a topographic feature at the mouth of an estuary, a distortion of the pycnocline may form downstream of the feature. If conditions are such that this lee wave breaks, then its collapse may generate internal waves traveling in both directions. However, they believe it is more likely that as the tide begins to lessen, the lee wave moves upstream against the decreasing flow, and evolves either as a series of solitary internal waves or as a dispersive wave system. By assuming that the waves were traveling upstream, New et al. (1986b) are able to predict a consistent generation site that coincides with a distinct increase in the water depth. The generation and role of internal waves in fjords has also received extensive attention. In coastal oceans and in fjords such waves are generated by the steepening of the internal tide (Holloway, 1987) and by tidal flows over sills (Apel et al., 1985; Farmer and Smith, 1978). Fjords are glacially carved estuaries, typically deep and stratified, often consisting of several interconnected basins partly separated from one another by sills (Freeland and Farmer, 1980). Farmer and Smith (1980) have studied the interaction of tidal flows over a sill in Knight Inlet, British Columbia. The resulting internal waves and shear flow instabilities were found to influence water exchange and mixing processes within the inlet. Similar findings concerning the generation of internal waves over sills in fjords have also been reported (Cummins et al., 2003; Farmer and Freeland, 1983; Freeland, 1980; Hibiya, 1988; Stacey et al., 1995; Saucier and Chasse, 2000; Valle-Levinson et al., 2001). There have also been studies using radar and satellite images, together with numerical models (Brandt et al., 1996; Darnault and Uyusur, 2008; Jay et al., 2007; Lamb, 2004; Watson and Robinson, 1990, 1991).

River estuaries are the first region where fresh water and sea water encounters occur. A large part of their dynamics is affected by the competition between tidal stirring, mixing and freshwater input from upstream (Bowden and Gilligan, 1971; Hansen and Rattray, 1966; Jay and Smith, 1990; Nash et al., 2009). The dynamics of the far-field plumes are dominated by buoyancy, rotation of planets and wind forcing. Far-field plumes are low-salinity and mesoscale in character and disperse river water across the sea shore margins (Fong and Geyer, 2002; Hickey et al., 2005; Yankovsky and Chapman, 1997). There is increasing interest in the processes involved in their connection. Horner-Devine et al. (2009) point out four dynamics must be considered: 1. the resource (e.g., river estuary); 2. tidal plume; 3. recirculating plume (Horner-Devine, 2009; Yankovsky and Chapman, 1997); and 4. far-field plume.

In the summer, pronounced stratification often occurs in lakes due to surface heating, which results in the division of the density structure of the water body into a lighter upper layer overlying a heavier lower layer, forming the commonly recognized two-layer density distribution system, with a constant density in each layer (Wessels and Hutter, 1996). There is rarely major circulations in the majority of lakes with such stratification. Water motion is thus totally dominated by some type of internal adjustment or motion (Imberger, 1994). Wessels and Hutter (1996) also claimed that internal waves dominate such processes during summer stratification. Hence, internal waves have been identified as being an important mechanism for mixing as well as sediment and nutrient transport processes that occur in lakes. It can thus be said that the mechanisms contributing to internal wave generation and dissipation in lakes are similar to those identified in oceans and estuaries. However, these are more pronounced in lakes (Mortimer, 1974).

sec.title: 7. Experimental study of estuaries and lakes
7.1. Internal wave dissipation in estuaries
sec.p: The fluid mixing process can be represented by several non-dimensional numbers, which help classify different mixing regimes that may exist under given conditions. The most important numbers related to estuarine mixing are the Reynolds number, the Richardson number, and the Froude number. The energy in a wave decreases as it shoals, breaks, mixes and interacts with other waves, thus producing fluctuation and dissipation. As the internal wave propagates upstream, it may encounter a sufficiently strong current to cause shear instability, breaking, intense mixing and dissipation (New et al., 1986a). Measurements of vertical mixing in estuaries where there is a sudden change in the depth have been performed (Gardner and Smith, 1978; Kay and Jay, 2003; Partch and Smith, 1978; Peters, 1997; Schroder and Siedler, 1989; West and Shiono, 1988). Intense mixing develops when the internal Froude number exceeds a critical value. The internal Froude number can be defined as Fi = U/C, where U is the amplitude of the internal tide horizontal velocity, and C is the horizontal component of the phase velocity of the wave. For a two-layer flow, the critical Froude number is 1 (Kjerfve, 1988b). As the critical Froude number is reached, the wave energy tends to become concentrated near the area where the depth changes, while its amplitude grows, and eventually the wave breaks. The breaking process creates an area of active mixing which is then advected downstream. Internal waves generated by bottom topography can also break further upstream from their point of origin, if the stratification or the layer thickness decreases. Also, although they can be generated by both flood and ebb tides, they are more common in the latter, due to the increasing depth downstream. Turbulent diffusion typically occurs whilst the Richardson number Ri is less than 0.25, manifesting itself in the form of Kelvin-Helmholtz instabilities with a wavelength on the order of 1 or 2 meters in a shallow estuary. In the presence of velocity shear, the instabilities steepen, roll up, and eventually break down into turbulent ‘billows’ (Dyer, 1997). These billows have the effect of mixing water from above and below the interface.

sec.title: 7.2. Internal wave generation in lakes
sec.p: In many lakes, an initial basin-scale seiche will steepen due to nonlinear effects until the steepening is balanced by dispersive effects, generating ISWs. Packets of such solitary waves are frequently observed in lakes (Farmer, 1978; Hunkins and Fliegel, 1973; Thorpe et al., 1972). The main generating mechanisms for internal waves in lakes have been suggested by Saggio and Imberger (1998) to include wind, atmospheric fluctuations of pressure, buoyancy flux, interaction of basin scale motion with the bottom topography, and nonlinear wave–wave interaction. Wind over the surface of the lake generates large-scale internal gravity waves with relatively lower frequency. Wind action at the free surface acts to inject energy into the water column, causing a shallow interface to ‘tilt’, giving rise to internal waves (Antenucci et al., 2000; Monismith, 1986; Mortimer, 1952; Palmarsson et al., 2004; Spigel and Imberger, 1980; Stevens and Imberger, 1996).

Experimental evidence regarding the response of a two-density-layer fluid after the application of a surface shear stress is presented and discussed in Nino et al. (2003). In long narrow lakes, baroclinic mode internal wave packets can first be excited in response to strong, significant wind events (Farmer, 1978; Stevens et al., 1996, 2004). Aside from wind stress, lake morphometry and stratification are also important in controlling the shape and frequency of internal waves (Wiegand and Carmack, 1986). However, in small to medium sized lakes, in which the effects of the Earth's rotation can be neglected, the dominant response is a basin-scale standing wave known as an ‘internal seiche’ (Mortimer, 1974).

Simanjuntak et al. (2009) describes the effect of a stair-step bottom topography on the transmission of ISWs. In most numerical models the propagation of internal waves is characterized as a geophysical flow. Analytical methods can predict the effect of the piecewise linear and stair-step topography and describe the transmission and reflection of the ISWs. Simanjuntak et al. (2009) have applied the Estuary Lake and Coastal Model (ELCOM) to simulate the propagation of a train of small-amplitude internal gravity waves in a linearly stratified fluid. The ISW propagates through a variable depth rectangular channel. The resultant partial bottom cells and full bottom cells solutions from ELCOM agree well with the piecewise linear solutions and theoretical stair-step, respectively. Sakai and Redekopp (2010) employed a two-layer nonlinear model with forcing and damping to observe the generation and degeneration of wind-forced long internal waves in a narrow lake. They used the Korteweg-deVries type model equation to simulate the lake field. The parametric effects of wind-forcing and environmental conditions for variable topography and variable basin widths are examined. The results show that the modeling results for the energy loss and energy reflection during a shoaling incident compare well with the laboratory experiments.

The Columbia River flows into the Pacific Ocean between Washington State and Oregon State, United States (Figure 10). Two jetties constrict the river mouth so that it narrows from 10 km to 3.5 km to form an estuary where flow is discharged from the west into the relatively wide-open coastal ocean. At 8 km from the mouth is a relatively flat, shallow area with a water depth of d ≈20 m, which is more or less radially symmetric around the tip of the north bulwark. The area is called the ‘bar region.’ A 20 m deep shipping channel running from the river mouth to the southwest is an exception to this symmetry. There is a 20 m deep dredge pile at (x, y)=(−8,0) km. The coordinate system is almost aligned with the average river discharge and is vertical to the north-south shore. sec.title: 7.3. Internal wave dissipation in lakes
sec.p: The energy of oceanic internal waves in the ocean interior is dissipated through wave breaking. In contrast, Saggio and Imberger (1998) report that the largest part of internal wave energy is lost at lake boundaries. Dissipative processes occurring at lake boundaries may include reflection at sloping boundaries and shoaling over bottom slopes, resulting in shear instabilities and wave breaking (Bogucki and Garrett, 1993; Horn et al., 2001). These processes provide a significant source of energy for turbulent mixing and resuspension of sediments and nutrients (Imberger, 1994). As the reflection of internal waves from a sloping boundary has been identified as a major dissipator of energy and mechanism for turbulent mixing, it has become a subject of intense investigation. For example, field measurements in a small stratified lake have been investigated by Hondzo and Haider (2004), who report high levels of energy dissipation at the sloping boundaries in which the thickness of the turbulent layer depends on the dissipation of turbulent kinetic energy, the strength of stratification, the length of the sloping boundary, and the angle of inclination of the sloping boundary.

Gilbert and Garrett (1989) explain that when an internal wave is reflected off a sloping bottom, its frequency is conserved. The magnitude of the reflection angle, which the wave ray makes with the horizontal, is also conserved. However, there exists a critical frequency at which, upon reflection, the energy density and shear associated with the incident waves are greatly amplified, so that shear instability and energy dissipation are more likely to occur. This is referred to as critical reflection and occurs where local bottom slope matches the wave ray slope. Ivey and Nokes (1989) found that this critical reflection coincided with enhanced mixing. Internal wave shoaling over a bottom slope is also associated with dissipation of internal wave energy and mixing. Velocity shear at the boundary is thought to contribute to the turbulent boundary layer over the bottom of the lake (Saggio and Imberger, 1998). Thorpe (1995) suggests that as internal waves interact with bed roughness, they generate secondary waves, which break in the velocity and density field of the primary wave, to create off slope turbulence. For additional information, analysis of the energetics of these waves suggests that the waves associated with mixing and turbulent events will dissipate their energy rapidly within the lake interior (Boegman et al., 2003; Etemad-Shahidi and Imberger, 2001; Herb and Stefan, 2005; Horn et al., 2001; Stevens et al., 2005; Wüest and Lorke, 2003).

sec.title: 8. Discussion and conclusions
sec.p: Many fronts are affected by strong speed convergence in which they are close to the river mouth. The performance of the fronts with horizontal density gradients is inconsistent. The term ‘reverse front’ is coined for the initial expansion of a salty, dense fluid colliding with fresh, receiving water. When this happens the situation is complex. The reasons are as follows: (1) the river mouth has a strong temporal variability in composition (r (t)) and flow rate Q (t); (2) the shallow bathymetry affects the fluid discharge; (3) in the vicinity of an estuary, freshwater plume remnants are common. The work focuses on the area around a shallow bar (x<-8 km) in an offshore region. The plume in this area develops due to freely propagating gravity current (Kilcher and Nash, 2010). The propagation of ISWs, their evolution and transformation in a stratified two-layer system over a submerged obstacle are discussed. Numerous remote sensing and in situ measurements have been made. The results show that the dynamics of the propagating waves are affected by the shoaling effect and changes in the local bottom topography. Many researchers in the field of physical oceanography have worked to explain, predict and understand the phenomena of internal waves. Many have also focused on explaining why internal waves are produced and predicting the intensity of internal waves given the specific seabed topography. Some researchers, such as Hsu and Ariyaratnam (2000), Chen and Hsu (2005), and Chen (2009), argue that depression type ISWs may be important in triggering sediment suspension in swash areas.

Irregular bathymetry includes large underwater mountains which result in the concentration of wave energy in some nearshore regions. Sometimes there is more compensation than the areas of concern for the above-mentioned wave attenuation. In fact, the most significant wave height and strongest wave power happen in situations where the water depth is under 100 m. The exception of the most energetic case happens with water depths under 50 m. The location of maximum wave height is the same as that of maximum wave power in all situations. Modeling of nearshore wave power and height show similarities to the related position and shape of energy centralized regions in all cases. The data, compared to the real values, are different (Iglesias and Carballo, 2010). Swaters and Flierl (1991) and Sutyrin et al. (2003) point out that the eddy-slope interaction can cause strong wave dispersion. The shelf-ring interaction in the above-mentioned situation can generate topographic RWs. The process of eddy exchange is not thought to be restricted to the inflow in the upper layer and export in the lower layer. This situation is not like most box models of input and output. Baker-Yeboah (2008) used mixed baroclinic and barotropic eddies coupled to the water column to understand the circulation and transport of cyclonic eddies.

Recently, new insight has led to the understanding that asymmetric barotropic tides with strong eastward currents are part of the internal tidal release mechanism, which contribute to strong westward moving solitons. If the strong eastward currents uplift isotherms that are higher on the west side of the ridge, this allows a huge amount of potential and kinetic energy on the west side. This situation is similar to the first modeled elevation wave, which propagates away from the ridge and its back slope disperses into solitons. Asymmetry in phase speeds and the small energy flux generated by lee waves are included in nonlinearities, which increase the energy density and generate soliton strength (Buijsman et al., 2010). D’asaro and Lien (2007) observed high frequency internal waves in tidal solibores which contribute a small portion of the whole internal wave energy in vast intermittent packets. Actually, internal tides are ubiquitous and have similar amplitudes. In fact, their contribution is more kinetic energy. Equally, incoherent internal waves generate more energy in a rough topography and are more common than the infrequent solibores.

Several questions arise from the literature, especially with regard to the nature of larger scale flow fields and the relative structures and intensity of the turbulence of internal waves. These questions are as follows:
What is the nature of vertical circulation in regions? Is it tidal coupled? What is the main function of the near surface across isobaths’ warm water invasion, which plays a role in the overall obviously downwelling state of the flow field? What is the main function played in rising near the bottom shear and increasing turbulence within the bottom mixing layer?
With warm water invasion, what is the physics of the intense frontal structure generated by this situation? What role does turbulence play in its evolution?
What is the function of the near surface offshore across isobaths advection in IW strain caused by shear enhancement?

These are interesting question that may need more modern equipment and numerical modeling strategies to solve and more data to find good results (Goodman and Wang, 2009; Chen, 2011b).
